Or, in the words of the VC: â€œthey might see this person speaking to them at an open day, or in Freshersâ€™ Week, then possibly not see this person ever again.â€That is not the approach that Charlie Jeffery wants to take. He voiced his desire to â€œbe a bit differentâ€ wanted to engage directly with the wider student population at York. He tells us that he hopes this will make the position of VC less â€œmysterious to students.â€

When setting out just what it is he does, he tells us he has three main roles:

1. Chief Academicâ€œI lead the research at the University [and] en-sure we perform at the highest level in that academic area.â€

2. Chief Executive The University is â€œa big organisation with a big budget, Iâ€™m responsible for making sure that money is deployed effectively.â€

Rent
Touching upon the colleges, Charlie Jeffery tells us how he â€œhopes to make more of that,â€ because â€œitâ€™s quite special to York. There arenâ€™t many places which have a college system. Image: Arian Kriesch
University Strikes
We interviewed the Vice Chancellor in late November just as the last rounds of strikes were under-way. Talking to him about the part of the dispute he has control over, pay casualisation, we ask him if he will commit to improving things for staff who feel they are not being valued. Perhaps by ending one year contracts? He replies that heâ€™s â€œhearing thatâ€™s the biggest issue,not just here but across UK picket lines too. Iâ€™ve raised this with our local UCU, saying Iâ€™m happy to have a conversation about casual staffing, pay gaps, and workload issues which are all bundled up into the UCEA locally focused action."

â€œWhen we have 28 different academic units, we have all sorts of practices and I think understanding the situation across all that diversity is a good step towards ensuring we have high quality employment con-tracts for our staff.â€He adds: â€œa former colleague at the University of Edinburgh had a mantra: â€œhappy staff, happy students. I think thereâ€™s something to that.â€

We then pointed out how the Vice Chancellor of Essex penned a letter supporting the strikes, saying that the trustees of the pension fund wereâ€œ overly cautiousâ€in allocating money .We asked Charlie Jeffery if he was willing to say that the striking lecturers deserve more compensation?â€œMy position is that we have had a second bout of industrial action in two years, and this obviously isnâ€™t good. We need to find a method tackling this issue in an enduring way. Thatâ€™s got some difficulties. This is partly because the national regulation system for pension schemes, and the pensions regulator who interprets government policy to set guidelines for the schemes to follow, they set certain assumptions about how you do valuations. There is lots of dispute around those assumptions.â€œI was a supporter right at the start of the joint expert panel process, which was the idea that the organisation for the pensions dispute, and UCU, should jointly work on some of those assumptions, anyhow the scheme might be governed best in the future.â€

A different kind of Vice Chancellor?

Climate change
One of the new Vice-Chancellorâ€™s first acts as VC was to announce that the University had divested from itâ€™s holdings in fossil fuel companies. We asked him what else the University can do to help become more sustainable. His answer... â€œAll sorts!â€Good answer we quip.The VC then sets out in more detail whatâ€™s being done. â€œOne of the first things I did was to effectively reboot the working group we had on sustainability issues,and to give it a different remit, and a sense of expectation on timescale. The goal has to be about three things... One is thinking about University operations,and carbon emissions associated with it, and we have to work within the constraints of our 1960's buildings,which arenâ€™t particularly carbon efficient.Secondly, we have brilliant research across academic departments here on climate change. I think we can do more to bring that together to make a bigger impact,both here and in the outside world.Thatâ€™s where we will have our biggest effect on the climate crisis and its impact on global warming, if we can get our technologies, and our insights adopted widely. And perhaps most importantly, itâ€™s students.

This was the VCâ€™s first interview with Nouse. A new VC with anew record, new goals, and priorities. Our job is to see how successful our new Vice-Chancellor will be.
